taxonAuthor: Miranda, Branch, Collins, Hirano, Marques & Griffiths, 2017

texts.shortText:
Stauromedusae are a small group of sedentary medusae that are attached ‘upside-down’ to the substratum by an adhesive disc. From the basal disc arises a stalk that spreads out into an umbrella-like oral disc with a central mouth encircled by short arms, which normally bear clusters of small, knobbed tentacles. There are only about 50 described species worldwide and only 4 in South Africa.

This recently discovered species was only formally named in 2017 and is currently known from only a small area extending from False Bay to Betty’s Bay in the SW Cape. It has a very short stalk and four widely spread, stiff, reddish-brown arms, each of which branches near the tips, which are armed with tufts of short tentacles. The upper surface is covered in nodular lobes (hence the allusion to pearls).

Global: Endemic to South Africa. 

Local/Regional: Very restricted known range from False Bay to Betty’s Bay.

This little-known but interesting upside-down jellyfish is known from relatively few published records across a very small range and is usually found attached to the fronds of kelps and other large algae.
Thought to feed on small crustaceans, especially copepods, amphipods and ostracods that live on the surfaces of the host algae.

Unlike most jellyfish Stauromedusae do not have an alternating polyp and medusa lifecycle. Sexually mature medusae release sperm and eggs into the water, which merge to form creeping planula larvae that settle and develop directly into new attached Stauromedusae.

A second member of this genus, C. capensis is known from just a single South African specimen collected from Sargassum in an intertidal rockpool near East London in the 1930s, and has subsequently been recorded from just one other individual collected in Brazil! It is more upright and has pad-like adhesive structures at the base of the arms beneath the tentacles. It would be exciting to try to rediscover that species and determine its true distribution.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 50).
